data.text:
RT @bariweiss: THREAD: THE TWITTER FILES PART TWO. 

TWITTER’S SECRET BLACKLISTS.
Start your engines…
@bariweiss Reporters resumed searches through Twitter Files material – a lot of it – today. The next installment of “The Twitter Files” will appear @bariweiss. Stay tuned.
@bariweiss The news that Baker was reviewing the “Twitter files” surprised everyone involved, to say the least. New Twitter chief Elon Musk acted quickly to “exit” Baker Tuesday.

@bariweiss Baker is a controversial figure. He has been something of a Zelig of FBI controversies dating back to 2016, from the Steele Dossier to the Alfa-Server mess. He resigned in 2018 after an investigation into leaks to the press.
@bariweiss The first batch of files both reporters received was marked, “Spectra Baker Emails.” https://t.co/24a9NhjosB
@bariweiss “My jaw hit the floor,” says Weiss.

Over the weekend, while we both dealt with obstacles to new searches, it was @BariWeiss who discovered that the person in charge of releasing the files was someone named Jim. When she called to ask “Jim’s” last name, the answer came back: “Jim Baker.”

The process for producing the “Twitter Files” involved delivery to two journalists (Bari Weiss and me) via a lawyer close to new management. However, after the initial batch, things became complicated.

We can now tell you part of the reason why. On Tuesday, Twitter Deputy General Counsel (and former FBI General Counsel) Jim Baker was fired. Among the reasons? Vetting the first batch of “Twitter Files” – without knowledge of new management.
On Friday, the first installment of the Twitter files was published here. We expected to publish more over the weekend. Many wondered why there was a delay.
THREAD: Twitter Files Supplemental

urls.title: Episode 15: : "America This Week," with Matt Taibbi and Walter Kirn
urls.description: Listen now (59 min) | Walter and Matt discuss the Twitter Files and Matt's recent Munk Debates appearance

data.text: New America This Week! In which @walterkirn and I talk about certain events… https://t.co/ZgZ5azXBlh
Good night, everyone. Thanks to all those who picked up the phone in the last few days.

It's been a whirlwind 96 hours for me, too. There is much more to come, including answers to questions about issues like shadow-banning, boosting, follower counts, the fate of various individual accounts, and more. These issues are not limited to the political right.

The problem with the "hacked materials" ruling, several sources said, was that this normally required an official/law enforcement finding of a hack. But such a finding never appears throughout what one executive describes as a "whirlwind" 24-hour, company-wide mess. https://t.co/aONKCROEOd
There are multiple instances in the files of Dorsey intervening to question suspensions and other moderation actions, for accounts across the political spectrum

An amazing subplot of the Twitter/Hunter Biden laptop affair was how much was done without the knowledge of CEO Jack Dorsey, and how long it took for the situation to get "unfucked" (as one ex-employee put it) even after Dorsey jumped in.

36.Twitter files continued: 
"THE FIRST AMENDMENT ISN’T ABSOLUTE” 
Szabo’s letter contains chilling passages relaying Democratic lawmakers’ attitudes. They want “more” moderation, and as for the Bill of Rights, it's "not absolute" https://t.co/cWdNYIprp8
35.Szabo reports to Twitter that some Hill figures are characterizing the laptop story as “tech’s Access Hollywood moment”: https://t.co/JTvXoQh6ZK

34.NetChoice lets Twitter know a “blood bath” awaits in upcoming Hill hearings, with members saying it's a "tipping point," complaining tech has “grown so big that they can’t even regulate themselves, so government may need to intervene.” https://t.co/2EE1NlWQ5k

33.Within a day, head of Public Policy Lauren Culbertson receives a ghastly letter/report from Carl Szabo of the research firm NetChoice, which had already polled 12 members of congress – 9 Rs and 3 Democrats, from “the House Judiciary Committee to Rep. Judy Chu’s office.” https://t.co/UpBoq97QkB
32.Khanna tries to reroute the conversation to the First Amendment, mention of which is generally hard to find in the files: https://t.co/Tq6l7VMuQL
Gadde replies quickly, immediately diving into the weeds of Twitter policy, unaware Khanna is more worried about the Bill of Rights: https://t.co/U4FRLYYPaY

30. In one humorous exchange on day 1, Democratic congressman Ro Khanna reaches out to Gadde to gently suggest she hop on the phone to talk about the “backlash re speech.” Khanna was the only Democratic official I could find in the files who expressed concern. https://t.co/TSSYOs5vfy
29. A fundamental problem with tech companies and content moderation: many people in charge of speech know/care little about speech, and have to be told the basics by outsiders. To wit:
28. To which former Deputy General Counsel Jim Baker again seems to advise staying the non-course, because “caution is warranted”: https://t.co/tg4D0gLWI6
27. Former VP of Global Comms Brandon Borrman asks, “Can we truthfully claim that this is part of the policy?” https://t.co/Rh5HL8prOZ
26. By this point “everyone knew this was fucked,” said one former employee, but the response was essentially to err on the side of… continuing to err. https://t.co/2wJMFAUBoe

https://t.co/j4EeXEAw6F can see the confusion in the following lengthy exchange, which ends up including Gadde and former Trust and safety chief Yoel Roth. Comms official Trenton Kennedy writes, “I'm struggling to understand the policy basis for marking this as unsafe”: https://t.co/w1wBMlG33U

24. “They just freelanced it,” is how one former employee characterized the decision. “Hacking was the excuse, but within a few hours, pretty much everyone realized that wasn’t going to hold. But no one had the guts to reverse it.”
23. The decision was made at the highest levels of the company, but without the knowledge of CEO Jack Dorsey, with former head of legal, policy and trust Vijaya Gadde playing a key role.

22. Although several sources recalled hearing about a “general” warning from federal law enforcement that summer about possible foreign hacks, there’s no evidence - that I've seen - of any government involvement in the laptop story. In fact, that might have been the problem...

urls.title: Distribution of hacked material policy
urls.description: We don’t condone attempts to compromise or infiltrate computer systems for malicious purposes.

data.text: 21. Strom’s note returned the answer that the laptop story had been removed for violation of the company’s “hacked materials” policy: https://t.co/EdTa2xbXn1 https://t.co/KQFRiKYKkb

20.This led public policy executive Caroline Strom to send out a polite WTF query. Several employees noted that there was tension between the comms/policy teams, who had little/less control over moderation, and the safety/trust teams: https://t.co/0IFnVPCOgY

19. White House spokeswoman Kaleigh McEnany was locked out of her account for tweeting about the story, prompting a furious letter from Trump campaign staffer Mike Hahn, who seethed: “At least pretend to care for the next 20 days.” https://t.co/CcXTfsdzCT

18. Twitter took extraordinary steps to suppress the story, removing links and posting warnings that it may be “unsafe.” They even blocked its transmission via direct message, a tool hitherto reserved for extreme cases, e.g. child pornography.

data.text: 17. On October 14, 2020, the New York Post published BIDEN SECRET EMAILS, an expose based on the contents of Hunter Biden’s abandoned laptop: https://t.co/q4zaMw6aVV
16. The Twitter Files, Part One: How and Why Twitter Blocked the Hunter Biden Laptop Story
Okay, there was more throat-clearing about the process, but screw it, let's jump forward
12. The resulting slant in content moderation decisions is visible in the documents you’re about to read. However, it’s also the assessment of multiple current and former high-level executives.

urls.title: Twitter Profile: Summary
urls.description: Twitter organization profile. Contributions in the 2022 cycle: $185,267. Lobbying in 2022: $970,000. Outside Spending in the 2022 cycle: $0.

data.text: 11. This system wasn't balanced. It was based on contacts. Because Twitter was and is overwhelmingly staffed by people of one political orientation, there were more channels, more ways to complain, open to the left (well, Democrats) than the right. https://t.co/sa1uVRNhuH https://t.co/K1xmqQ0TrD
10.Both parties had access to these tools. For instance, in 2020, requests from both the Trump White House and the Biden campaign were received and honored. However:
9. Celebrities and unknowns alike could be removed or reviewed at the behest of a political party: https://t.co/4uzkHnQ65E

8. By 2020, requests from connected actors to delete tweets were routine. One executive would write to another:  “More to review from the Biden team.” The reply would come back: “Handled.” https://t.co/mnv0YZI4af

7. Slowly, over time, Twitter staff and executives began to find more and more uses for these tools. Outsiders began petitioning the company to manipulate speech as well: first a little, then more often, then constantly.
6. As time progressed, however, the company was slowly forced to add those barriers. Some of the first tools for controlling speech were designed to combat the likes of spam and financial fraudsters.
5. In an early conception, Twitter more than lived up to its mission statement, giving people “the power to create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.”
4. Twitter in its conception was a brilliant tool for enabling instant mass communication, making a true real-time global conversation possible for the first time.

3. The “Twitter Files” tell an incredible story from inside one of the world’s largest and most influential social media platforms. It is a Frankensteinian tale of a human-built mechanism grown out the control of its designer.
2. What you’re about to read is the first installment in a series, based upon thousands of internal documents obtained by sources at Twitter.
1. Thread: THE TWITTER FILES

@scootluc Then let it be terrible. Who cares? Why talk about not “allowing” it?

@matthewstoller I’m talking about cheering on things like Apple and Amazon teaming up to remove the Parler or Twitter app because they don’t approve of their speech policies. If any Republicans favor that they suck too.

urls.title: Apple's 'monopoly power' over iPhone app distribution gives it outsized profits, antitrust committee says
urls.description: The 450-page report from the Democratic majority staff of the House Judiciary Committee looks at Apple's control of its App Store, the only way for consumers to install apps or software on an iPhone, along with Apple's proclivity to buy smaller technology companies and turn them into features for Apple products.

data.text: If I am, so is the House Judiciary Committee apparently https://t.co/BN0RCnf64i https://t.co/WDzPQIEBsC

Even the concept of being proud to think in step with a group is new. Having your own idiosyncratic set of beliefs was considered healthy until pretty recently. Now individualism is often just seen as a stalking-horse for wrong-think https://t.co/iBdMIXx7TD
In the Bush years the word “liberal” was stripped of meaning beyond, “person of suspect political loyalties.” Now “right wing” is used the same way. https://t.co/leG4yrjcPT

I’m the one who hasn’t switched belief systems. I was against monopolies before and still am. I supported free speech before and still do. Hilarious to call it progressivism when you cheer for giant monopolistic corporations like Apple and Google to control information flow https://t.co/Jaawlr4y4B
@WhyNaught_ I like Japanese baseball and the Beastie Boys, so…
I could swear being anti-monopolist was a prerequisite for political liberals in the not-so-distant past. Now it’s encouraged, to facilitate de-platforming. https://t.co/f5NRMCVDWj
Basically, it’s an In Search Of episode, but it’s dangerous according to The Guardian because Joe Rogan likes it or something https://t.co/lTGFynnEg7
@0rf Likewise!

@o4z71tq0qy @FandySandy45 @aredmond75 Dude we know who the professor was. His name was Josef Mifsud and he’s Maltese. There are no Russians in the story, as even the FBI Deputy Director conceded in testimony https://t.co/u01g2EH8PS

urls.title: Copy of Hunter Biden laptop data appears genuine, independent experts find
urls.description: House Republicans say one of their top investigative priorities is the Biden family businesses, and Hunter Biden's purported laptop could be crucial to those investigations. CBS News commissioned an independent forensic review of what is believed to be Hunter Biden's laptop data. Catherine Herridge reports.

data.text: CBS News today came out with a story about how Hunter Biden’s laptop “appears genuine” - confirming what they ridiculed when the story first broke. Check out the video by @0rf below. https://t.co/gtl0KzDV9P https://t.co/gE90lAdp1A
RT @AshleyRindsberg: @mtaibbi "Russian disinformation" is the unfalsifiable metaphysic at the heart of every attempt to control who pulls t…

“The GRU has spoken.” “Russian intelligence, you mean?” “One hundred percent.”

That seems a little beyond a comment about fickleness. https://t.co/Buz8A11WNb https://t.co/jld6psNFzl

@lebesant “The GRU has spoken.” “Russian intelligence?” “100%.” 

But he’s not being specific, you say?
@o4z71tq0qy @FandySandy45 @aredmond75 With what “Russian” did Papadopoulos meet?

@daveblend Give me an example of an “unsupported claim” by them. If you say, “I think the Russians would like Trump back on Twitter,” that’s an opinion. If it’s, “the GRU hacked the poll,” that’s a claim.

tweets.text: 11. This system wasn't balanced. It was based on contacts. Because Twitter was and is overwhelmingly staffed by people of one political orientation, there were more channels, more ways to complain, open to the left (well, Democrats) than the right. https://t.co/sa1uVRNhuH https://t.co/K1xmqQ0TrD
10.Both parties had access to these tools. For instance, in 2020, requests from both the Trump White House and the Biden campaign were received and honored. However:
9. Celebrities and unknowns alike could be removed or reviewed at the behest of a political party: https://t.co/4uzkHnQ65E

8. By 2020, requests from connected actors to delete tweets were routine. One executive would write to another:  “More to review from the Biden team.” The reply would come back: “Handled.” https://t.co/mnv0YZI4af

7. Slowly, over time, Twitter staff and executives began to find more and more uses for these tools. Outsiders began petitioning the company to manipulate speech as well: first a little, then more often, then constantly.
6. As time progressed, however, the company was slowly forced to add those barriers. Some of the first tools for controlling speech were designed to combat the likes of spam and financial fraudsters.
5. In an early conception, Twitter more than lived up to its mission statement, giving people “the power to create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.”
4. Twitter in its conception was a brilliant tool for enabling instant mass communication, making a true real-time global conversation possible for the first time.

3. The “Twitter Files” tell an incredible story from inside one of the world’s largest and most influential social media platforms. It is a Frankensteinian tale of a human-built mechanism grown out the control of its designer.
2. What you’re about to read is the first installment in a series, based upon thousands of internal documents obtained by sources at Twitter.
1. Thread: THE TWITTER FILES

A wonderful evening in Toronto where @mtaibbi and I persuaded a packed auditorium at the Munk Debates that the mainstream media (especially the @nytimes and Malcolm @Gladwell) were not to be trusted. Final result a landslide to our side. Video to follow.

@munkdebate @mtaibbi @DouglasKMurray @Gladwell @michelleinbklyn @roythomsonhall Fantastic debate, Matt!!! There is an obvious problem with trust in the mainstream media. You were arguing with ostriches, especially @Gladwell, who didn't listen to a fucking thing you said on this problem.

@mtaibbi Regardless of the Guardian's histrionics, the show is terrible, for all the usual reasons that show are terrible
@mtaibbi Look at the opponents of antitrust legislation and you’ll find mostly Rs.
@mtaibbi Monopolistic like Apple? JFC gtfo. We’re you born yesterday?
@mtaibbi Been mulling how in-group/out-group bullying is the entire neoliberal mode now. https://t.co/1H9Ozzwjbi
@ElevenGrover @mtaibbi Binary thinkers can only conceptualize “my team” and “bad guys.” Which leads to absurd reasoning like this.
@mtaibbi Didn't have greenwald and taibbi become full throated right wing populists on my bingo card last decade but the whole timeline is getting weirder by the minute
@mtaibbi Wow, Oh on your profile pic:) why?

When Parler became the single most-downloaded app in the US after Trump’s banning, Dems like @AOC demanded Google and Apple remove it from their stores. They wisely obeyed and Parler was destroyed.

They’re trying to repeat this abuse of monopoly power to do this to Twitter. https://t.co/OafdVksJsg

I had zero interest in this show, but now that I've seen this not only am I watching it but I'm subjecting my family to it. A powerful reminder of something obvious but worth repeating endlessly: culture war is so great for business that OF COURSE we'll keep having it. https://t.co/AvUyzI4qKT

Maybe I'm overgeneralizing from a sample of two or three people but, like, the most prominent "misinformation reporters" are both very partisan and very often spread misinformation. The whole category is 🚩🚩🚩🚩🚩🚩🚩🚩🚩🚩🚩🚩🚩🚩.

@mtaibbi @TeamYouTube Emails can be “real” and still part of a misinformation campaign. Just look at the way innocuous emails were weaponized in 2016 against Clinton with the help of msm. Bannon and Rudy were explicit they wanted to try the same with Biden.

@mtaibbi @0rf Hey, Matt, was this supposed to be published as "satire", too? Did you ever bother to watch that Zuckerberg interview with Rogan? Because according to Mark Zuckerberg (the source you cite) the FBI never once mentioned Hunter Biden , Joe Biden, or a laptop. #HasBeen https://t.co/WG30Urwg1q

@mtaibbi @FandySandy45 @aredmond75 I don't know. Do you think the NYTimes was lying when it reported Papadopoulos pleaded guilty to lying about contacts with a "Russian professor" whom Pap knew had "substantial connections to Russian govt officials"?

MEDIA 2022: Hunter Biden's laptop is real.
MEDIA 2020: RUSSIAN DISINFORMATION! https://t.co/O66PJZNxlN
@mtaibbi "Russian disinformation" is the unfalsifiable metaphysic at the heart of every attempt to control who pulls the media levers.

I don’t have proof of Russian interference in the poll; however, it would be hard to disprove it.

What I am saying is this seems like a fickle way to reverse a permanent ban, esp after Musk said a moderation council would decide. Also: “moderation policy hasn’t changed”?
@FandySandy45 @aredmond75 @mtaibbi Looks true https://t.co/2IslJZqvWc

@mtaibbi Glenn Greenwald makes unsupported claims daily. Michael Tracey is a walking, talking unsupported claim. You're absolutely fine with those idiots, so let's not pretend like your standards would be applied universally if you ever actually got a show.
